reviewText:
Tower Wars is a tower defense game combined with army building. This indie title was released in August 2012, so has been around for a while coming in with about 400k owners on Steam.

As with other tower defense games, you start out with a blank battlefield, although this version of tower defense is slightly different to others, you are also fighting against an opponent, who is also building towers on their blank battlefield. The aim of the game is to get your army into the enemies base to destroy their castle before they destroy yours.  Tower Wars has two currency systems, Gold and Battle points - you are able to generate gold via the mines which are already located on your map; you can do the usual technique with tower defense games and upgrade them so that they generate more gold and are quicker at it. Battle points come through sending units to your opponent and working their way to the castle, this of course requires gold though.

You build units from your barracks with gold, there is a build queue which you can fill up however you please with different assorted units which you can train, and then push them all out in one go. Your barracks has a cool down so you can only push one wave out every 40 seconds or so. Some units are basic, some have their own special abilities, and some even increase the stats of the whole wave, regardless of whether they are near the units or not.

The tower building side of things is again, very similar to other tower defense games, you are able to position your towers pretty much anywhere you want on the map, allowing you to create all sorts of death traps, and corridors that your foe has to battle through, obviously the more ground the opponent has to cover, the more damage you can do to them with your turrets. There are plenty of the normal sort of turrets, such as cannons and arrow launchers, but there are also some really unique ones, such as a huge fan that pushes your opponents back in a certain direction, this makes for some great end of hallway traps!  All of the turrets are able to be upgraded in the usual fashion too, however I didn't really find the need to do that in the single player mode.

Tower Wars has a really nice looking graphic and art style; they are really polished and it looks like a lot of care and attention has gone into making this a beautiful steam-punk looking game.

The difficulty in Tower Wars takes a huge ramp up once you get past the tutorial. I will say though, the game's tutorial is really helpful and gets you to grips with the UI and all of the basic elements of the game. It does leave out a few bits that mean you have to go digging around and use a bit of trial and error to see what is what, but that's part of the fun of this type of game.  There are also an abundance of guides, and wiki posts out there if you really want to get into the nitty gritty of it.

Since the game is almost four years old now, the multiplayer scene seems to have died down a bit, at the time of writing this there are only  ~30 people playing the game, but thankfully the game does have the option for co-op, so that may peek the attention of some people

Technically, this game has a lot of graphical options, allowing you to cater it for your rigs power and capability, coming with plenty of resolution options too.

I have put about six hours into Tower Wars so far, and given that matches against the UI/Bots can sometimes last anywhere between 45 minutes and an hour, you can expect to get a lot of gameplay out of this even on the single player mode. If you manage to find yourself a group of friends to play this with, you are looking at a major time sink with ample amounts of fun and content.  I will definitely be carrying on playing Tower Wars after writing this review, since it also has that addicted sort of gameplay that I just cannot put down.

Thankfully, due to the price of Tower Wars being £5,59, I am going to strongly recommend this title, if it was any more I would have just said to pick it up when on sale due to the lack of multiplayer activity, but because it is already a low price as it stands, I can easily say you will get at least five or six hours of enjoyment out of it. Hardcore tower defense fans should not miss out on this game!

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

This is a steampunk themed competitive tower defence PvP game, which is quite an intriguing genre.

You build towers on a map composed from hexagon tiles, to defend from enemy armies. Nothing special here, typical set of towers available.

You send your own armies to attack enemy in order to get battle points which allow you to unlock new units and upgrade old ones. There's more freedom here, and if you know what you're doing, this is a great place to showcase your tactical skills, especially at late stages of the game when some interesting units are available.

There's also a little resources gathering aspect to the game.

Biggest trick is to efficiently balance your defence, offence, upgrades and resources. If you screw up anywhere, you're done.

There's one huge problem with this game, which is why this is a negative review. It has pretty much no tutorial available, no single-player campaign to gradually develop your skills, UI is un-intuitive, controls are messed up, etc. All you have are bots, weakest of which will probably defeat you up to five times untill you grasp basics of the game, and after that you only have try-and-fail approach to figure out why some more sophisticated things work and some don't.

And then, playing multiplayer, game becomes over-competetive pretty fast, so unless it's inline whith your character, you will not be able to really casually enjoy the game ...

It's a pity, if devs would've spent a little more time to implement decent in-game tutorial and usable UI and controlls, game would be much more playable.

reviewText:
Tower Wars is an interesting idea bogged down by its excessive attempts to condense and entire tower defense experience into a single match.

The basic concept of Tower Wars is a competitive TD game where you control both the towers and the enemies, and have to balance throwing tons of grunts at the enemy castle while building up your own defenses to keep theirs away. Adding onto this is a huge upgrade tree, from unlocking new grunt types, to passive upgrades for all units, to upgrading your towers and already unlocked grunts. Essentially everything can be upgraded several times over, and with a limited amount of resources you need to pay careful attention to what you invest in or else be overrun by the other player.

If this sounds like a lot to take in, that's because it is. Tower Wars is absurdly involved, as it takes the features that would normally be slowly added over the course of a typical TD game and instead gives you them all for the one self contained match you are already in. As a result it's incredibly overwhelming, and causes matches to stretch on for far longer than they have any right to. The tutorial match alone took nearly an hour, and my first match against the easiest AI opponent in the game about 30 minutes more (which ultimately ended in my defeat). If you're going up against a real human opponent of equal skill, expect this time per match to only rise further, which creates a huge commitment on the player that could ultimately prove for naught.

Ultimately Tower Wars asks too much of the player without giving them a reason to stick with it through the long periods of tedium that inevitably occur after the first 10-15 minutes when you've placed most of your towers and begin the long game of tug of war, as you incrementally chip away at each other's castles until someone gets a lucky break and finally pushes through. The concept is a really neat one, but the way it's executed here is dull and overly complex to the point I was begging for defeat simply so the match would be over. I love TD games, probably more than I should, but nothing about Tower Wars ever manifested itself into anything fun or engrossing and just left me feeling like I'd wasted my time and had nothing to show for it.

reviewText:
Tower Wars is the tower defense genre taken to its logical conclusion, a game where you both defend with towers and attack other peoples' towers. To that end it's mainly a multiplayer game, though the last major update added ten levels of bots to lose to without anyone knowing your shame. It's a good thing too, because the odds of you getting a match against a person aren't very good these days.

Each match gives you command over a castle, a barracks, and large tracts of hex-gridded land, all mirrored by your opponent. Your task is to send waves of attackers to destroy your foe's castle while maintaining a field of towers to defend your own castle. The resource that fuels both of these labors is gold, mined from upgradable plots in your territory, so right away you have a balance that must be struck between offense and defense. In addition, your attackers earn Battle Points for the time they spend (alive) in enemy territory. These points are used to unlock new units, upgrade your units, and upgrade your mines.

If all this is starting to sound complicated, well, it is. You need to be sending troops to attack, upgrading those troops, upgrading your mines, and managing your own towers, all based out of two resource pools. And yes, just the tower defense part is full-fledged tower defense, with the ability to place upwards of a hundred towers on a single map, of eight different types and three upgrade levels. Layering further complexity over that, while an interesting idea, makes the game a huge struggle to keep up with. It's basically Build Orders: The Game, so if that was your favorite part of Starcraft, there might be something here for you to latch onto.

Even so, it's hard to give a positive review to a multiplayer-focused game with no player base. None of my half-dozen attempts to find a match, ranked or unranked over several days, met with success. Poking around the forums it seems there are only a few dozen active players left, and there may be something wrong with matchmaking that the developers have not addressed. It's just as well, because the complexity pushes it up into DOTA territory, long matches and all. A single round can last thirty minutes to an hour, and a loss after all that time really hurts because it earns you nothing. There are no unlocks or points or anything to chase, just match after match. And when you can't even find one, that's a problem.

reviewText:
I recently got the game(2$ on discount) and played around 15times. I like it! It is a pretty good Maze building TD and it definetely worthed the 2$.
There are practically two types of games: Tower Defense and Tower Wars ( for those familiar with old Warcraft3 maps)

If you like competitive tower defense games, I'd say give it a shot!

Some game features:

Tower Defense type is played vs AI; Tower Wars types can be played both vs other players or vs AI.
It can be played in max 3v3 players, or 3 Co-op vs AI.
There are around 5-6 maps that you can play on, and every new round the layout is a little changed so you have to adapt your maze from game to game.
The game is based on two resources: gold and battle points.
Gold is earned every few seconds based on your income(which increases by buying/upgrading miners). Gold is used for building/upgrading towers and also for sending units.
Battle points are earned by the units you send out. Battle points are spent for unit upgrades, unlocking new units, buying miners

There aren't as many types of towers or creep units types as I'd wish but it ok:
- around 8 types of towers ( each can be upgraded 3 times - but it's a liniar upgrade, no branches or other abilities/customization of towers)
- around 10 units(again each with some upgrades)
- castle upgrades for armor or damage
- a pretty complex tree structure for speed/armor/shield/health and other stuff as general upgrades for all units

At first it was a little strange the way you choose/upgrade towers(hold and drag mouse) but I got used with it and then I found out you can also use key shortcuts(shift+click,ctrl+click)

reviewText:
I felt in love with Tower Wars concept since the very first WMW (Wintermaul Wars), which was just a simple UMS (custom map) for Warcraft 3 game. And this was around ten years ago, around 2004-2005. Long time ago...

Tower Wars is a strategy game. It combines classical TD (tower defense) elements with a war elements, where YOU are the one who sends the troops, not the AI. It's like taking old WMW concept and creating a game based on that. And, I must agree that it ended pretty well.

It's not an easy game, tower wars requires from you a tactical thinking and the willing to practice... much. By playing this title, you'll need to balance between the offense and the defense, You'll need to decide whether to upgrade existing towers, or create new ones, between upgrading existing troops and training new ones.

What I can say about this title... It's good. Graphics are nice, it's well balanced game, I didn't find any bigger issues, and I can really recommend this game. If you've ever played a tower defense game, and you liked the concept, you'll like this one even more. If you did not, I'd still give it a try, because game is awesome and building a strong defense is as important as attacking the enemy with strong troops.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Tower wars is a steampunk, competitive, Tower Defense game that challenges the preconceptions of the genre by putting you in control of not only your towers, but the lemmings that throw themselves at the defenses of your opponent.

It requires maintaining a delicate balance between building your towers and upgrading (and purchasing) your troops.  Focus too much on your towers, and your enemy will overwhelm you with a superior economy; but focus too much on creating an army and your defenses will fall to even the puniest wave.

The ecnomy of the game requires two currencies:  Gold (used to purchase troops, unlock new troops, and build and upgrade towers) which is mined through randomly placed mines that must be upgraded, and Battle Points (used to upgrade toops and mines) which is gained through sending troops into battle.  The interdependency of these two currencies further requires maintaining a delicate balance between offense and defense.

Battles can be decisive and quick if the skills are mismatched; but if you find a good opponent, then you'll find yourself in for a campaign of attrition which could take upwards of two hours.  It's a high stakes tower defense game that offers a high amount of replayability; but the lack of map content (three total) leaves a lot to be desired when it comes to diversity of content.

Tower Wars,
It's not your average tower defence game. Sure it has a survival mode to play it that way but that's not the sole action of this game. It's a tower defender and attacker! That's right you have to go on the offence or no matter how great you planning if you only defend you will fail. In fact if your balance of attach vs defence is even a little off you will fail. The computer baddys are tough, and may even break you heh.

The real grabber with this game though is the online portion. You can battle with or against friends and strangers from across the world. Yes I used the plural, you can join with up to two other people per team (3 total) for a 6 player game! This is a fantasticly fun way to play. Mixing more than one mind into the game makes it a lot of fun, and a bit more challenging. Things happen fast, so don't plan on a extended set up period. A game can be completed in just a few turns or it can last for up to an hour (In one battle I had so far) all depending on the skill level and a little bit of luck in mine placements which are always random.

reviewText: If you're a fan of the tower defense genre, Tower Wars is a surprisingly good offering. I must warn that it is primarily head-to-head tower defense, so none of the storyline or RPG tie-ins that other titles offer. Still, it's very well-made and is a great example of the genre. You build towers to channel and kill enemies, while balancing resource production, units to pressure your enemy, your defenses, and upgrading your units to do more damage. It's a pretty interesting priority based system where every game plays out very differently based on how you and your opponent react. The way it makes me think is more like a RTS than a tower defense game. Pretty good.

I love this game but the balance against bots(which is how most people learn to play a new game) is way off. At round two the bots will start to send upgraded and new units at you continually. In that same amount of time I am able to put up 3-4 towers and send out a wave of 5-6 units. Difficulty seems very broken and punishing to me.

That being said. I really like this game. Love the concept, the graphics, voice acting, music(amazing music actually). The brutal bot difficulty(why not have an adjustable difficulty for single player?) is keeping me from being completely in love with it.

I do absolutely recommend this game though. It is very well done and multiplayer matches are an absolute blast(especially with a group of friends on skype or local lan.) My only complaint is the one that I mentioned involving the single player experience.

reviewText:
I really didn't pay any attention to this game when I picked it up in a bundle last year. Idled for cards, made some money. My son actually played it, then challenged me to a match. I've got to say its a pretty fun game.

The jist of it is that you play tower defense against your opponent while also sending waves of units against them. There is gold from mining and battlepoints from sending units (more BP the longer they last on the map). You need both. Towers and units are bought with gold, upgrades are bought with BP, and units are unlocked with both.

What I find interesting is that you need to balance sending out lots of units to get upgrades, and you need to keep your maze strong to stop enemy units from getting BP for upgrades.

The main downside to this game is that there are some fairly predictable setups that will win matches against players that expect a regular TD game. If you find an opponent that uses a similar setup, the game can progress, but otherwise its usually quite one sided.

Overall, I think its a fun game, with some features that make it different from the rest of the TD out there.

reviewText:
Mein ursprüngliche gepostetes Review erschien unter:

www.LetsPlayPromotion.com

http://www.letsplaypromotion.com/tower-wars-review/

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Tower-Defense Games sind immer so eine Sache. Entweder sind sie von den Farben her zu knallig, inhaltlich zu abgedreht, zu langatmig, zu schwer, zu schnell usw. usw. Für einen echten Nörgler kann die Liste nicht lang genug sein. Erfreulicherweise konnte ich mich bisher vor allen selbstgemachten Negativerfahrungen bewahren, da ich bis zum Test von „Tower Wars“ eine wahre Tower-Defense Jungfrau war. Daher kann ich vorab sagen, dass mich das Game mehr als positiv überrascht hat. Aber kommen wir doch erst einmal dazu, was die Damen und Herren von SuperVillain Studios so geschaffen haben.


TOWER WARS REVIEW – WAS IST DAS EIGENTLICH?

Nach kurzer Spielzeit wurde für mich eines sofort deutlich. Tower Wars ist ein ordentliches Tower-Defense Game, mit ordentlich Zack! Aber kommen wir doch erst mal zum Inhalt. Obwohl ich an dieser Stelle langatmig die Mechanik eines Tower-Defense Spiel erklären könnte…. ach was solls. Wie man vielleicht aus dem englischen Ableiten kann, beinhalten Tower-Defense Games Türme und Abwehr. Kombiniert man das ganze kommt man schnell auf den Trichter, dass die Türme als Mittel zum Zweck verwendet werden. Und zwar um seine eigene Basis vor den anrückenden Gegenerhorden zu verteidigen um parallel dazu, mit seinen eigenen Truppen, dass gegnerische Lager bis auf die Grundmauern niederzubrennen. Klingt das nicht schön? Nicht nur ähnlich, sondern exakt so, geht es auch in Tower Wars zu. Kommen wir daher also mal zum eigentlichen Spiel.

TOWER WARS – GAMEPLAY

Im Großen und Ganzen ist Tower Wars sehr simpel aufgebaut. Man hat neben dem Tutorial (welches verhältnismäßig lang, humorvoll ist und auf angenehme Weise die Spielmechanik erklärt) weitere Spielmodi wie z.B. den Multiplayer und der Kampf gegen die künstliche Intelligenz. Bevor man ein Spiel gegen Mensch oder KI startet, empfiehlt es sich das Tutorial zu spielen. Hier werden alle wichtigen Spielmechaniken erklärt und dies auf eine sehr humorvolle Art und Weise. Wir lassen jetzt mal unsere Fantasie spielen und stellen uns vor, wir sind im Game. Was jetzt? Im Endeffekt ist das Spielprinzip sehr einfach. Man selber (als auch der der Feind) hat eine eigene Basis, die durch das Setzen von Türmen, vor den heranrückenden Feinden beschützt werden soll. Dazu hat man eine Auswahl an unterschiedlichen Türmen. Egal ob es sich dabei um überdimensionale Armbrüste handelt, Teslaspulenartige Türme die an die Zeiten von Command & Conquer erinnern, oder riesenhafte Katapulte für Distanzangriffe. Tower Wars bietet alles! Türme haben in Tower Wars allerdings noch eine weitere Funktion. Neben der Verteidigung dienen sie auch als Möglichkeit, um die KI vor ihrer vorgegebenen Marschroute abzulenken. So laufen die Gegner immer auf einer exakt vorgegebenen Route lang, die im Spiel entweder blau oder rot markiert ist. Durch das setzen der Türme, kann diese Route entsprechend verlängert werden, was auch nötig ist. Der Feind baut im Laufe des Spiel größere und stärkere Einheiten, was ein Risiko für den Durchbruch der eigenen Verteidigungslinie immens erhöht. Neben dem Bau von Türmen ist es allerdings auch möglich eigene Einheiten zu bauen. Dies wird ermöglicht durch Gold und Battlepoints. Gold lässt sich einfach in den umliegenden Minen absammeln, während Battlepoints durch blutige Schlachten gewonnen werden können. Neben dem Einheitenbau lassen sich mit Battlepoints und Gold auch Upgrades erkaufen um die feindliche Basis noch schneller zu stürmen.

TOWER WARS – GRAFIK UND SOUND

Was lässt sich schon sagen. Ich persönlich finde die Grafik sehr gelungen. SuperVillain Studios ist ein Indie Studio welches nicht über ein Budget von mehreren Millionen Dollar verfügt, daher ist das was dem Konsumenten präsentiert wird mehr als ausreichend. Es gibt keine groben Ecken und Kanten und mir sind bisher keine groben Grafikpatzer aufgefallen. Der Sound ist allerdings erste Sahne! Neben den klangvollen Geräuschen ist insbesondere die Vertonung der Stimmen PERFEKT gelungen. Selten habe ich einen so hervorragenden, englischen Akzent in einem Videospiel erleben dürfen. Einfach nur herrlich.

FAZIT

Machen wir es kurz und schmerzlos. Tower Wars ist ein überaus gelungener Indie Titel von SuperVillain Studios, der sich nicht hinter anderen Tower-Defense Spielen zu verstecken brauch. Das Gameplay ist schnell, manchmal vielleicht etwas zu schnell. Mit etwas Übung und stimmiger Aufteilung seiner Türme ist die erste Defense Line geschaffen, wodurch erst mal brav Battlepoints gesammelt werden können. Tower Wars ist auf Steam erhältlich und dies sogar in mehreren Versionen. Während eine Kopie des Spiels schlappe 7,99 Euro kostet, ist das Tower Wars Team Pack, bestehend aus drei Kopien, für 19,90 Euro zu haben. Für Tower-Defense Fans sollte das Spiel durch die unterschiedlichen Spielmodi  lange Spaß machen. Ansonsten eignet es sich durch den Preis von 7,99 Euro auch wunderbar zu giften.

Zusammenfassend lässt sich sagen, dass Tower Wars ein spaßiges Spiel für Einsteiger ist, welches besonders durch seinen Humor und Preis beeindruckt. Daher verteile ich für Tower Wars ganze vier von fünf Sternen.

All in all, a promising game but lacking execution and less polished. Despite the workshop implemented already, there's little to none content in it. Sad, but that's true. Maybe with longer developer supports and a few sales here and there the game can be improved and has bigger player base.

Summary: Misleading, poorly designed clickfest

Detail:
Taking a look at the cartoonish, over-the-top graphics, one gets the impression that this is a family friendly, childish (in a good way) game, great for relaxing and enjoying some simple cartoon destruction with a laid back style and maybe mild challenges.  Going through the not-very-detailed tutorial, the joking dialogue confirms your impression.  When the guidance is complete (having forced you forward so you couldn't really watch the effects of what you were told to do since the action was off the screen while the text pop-ups prevented you from scrolling), however, and you are told to defeat the AI that was allegedly designed to be laughably simple, you eerily discover that it is strangely not so easy.

Brushing it off and moving on to the first opponent AI, the real game quickly shows itself.  Still not really sure when you are supposed to use which towers and units (i.e. what the strengths are meant to be), you are left to figure it out in real-time.  A bit of delay and boring start ensues, but the pace quickly picks up.  Expect to loose if you actually try to take the time to read the in-game descriptions for each unit and tower to learn as the AI rapidly ramps up its waves.  I am quite a tower game rookie, but since the game gives the impression that it would fit well for that situation, it is telling that I lost 3 or 4 times until beating the very first AI opponent (then beating the second on the first try since the design is so repetative before giving up on the third from the stupidity).  Most annoying is the fact that there is no time to really think about how to lay out your towers, the waves come too fast, you have to memorize the map and already know what to do.  The fact that single player was an after-thought is quite evident given that, pathetically, there is nothing even as simple as a game speed adjustment.  So while the AI happily processes away at the speed of electricity, its all on you to try to out-click it - the single biggest factor in destroying the potential enjoyability of the game - it is nothing but rushing to keep up. reviewText:
This game has a serious User Interface problem. It struggles to communicate even the most basic things for the Tower Defence genre. For example: when you are going to place a tower, the menu that shows tower placement options actually gets in the way of the range indicator for the towers. Also, the tower placement menu is only visible for as long as you hold the mouse button down; and if you accidentaly misclick a tile, that counts as pressing the button (to show the menu) and releasing it (to select an action i.e. placing a tower), which means you'll built lots of towers by mistake. The buttons in the interface are way too small, there are no information tooltips for most of them (what the hell does the exclamation mark do exactly? It turns red when I click it, but that's it). The fonts are ugly and inconsitent. The creeps' HP bars are hard to read. The pathing of the creeps is smart, but it doesn't show you how it will change until you actually place your towers, so you have to think extra hard before you do anything. Even deleting units from your units queue is painfully hard, you have to double click each individual unit (also, this information is nowhere to be found, I figured it out by mistake). Seriously, the developers need to take a cold, hard look at their User Interface and User Experience. The game is frustrating before it even starts.

These interface issues were enough to make my experience (with a friend, actually) a nightmare, to the point where I ragequitted a co-op game that I was winning. Aside from that, I'd say that the game actually tries to be funny (in the tutorial and in all the tips and vocal taunts), but really it is not. And bad comedy is worse than no comedy at all.

The more I think about this game, the more I find things to hate about it. Having two different resources seems like a good idea in theory, but it sucks in game. There are loads of options everywhere and on everything, but most of them are not actually viable - they're useless clutter. You have 3 mines (where you get your resources from) and you can upgrade each one individually. Why? Why not have just one place to control your resource gathering? By the way, the Tower Defence" aspect of this game is secondary. This is a resource-management game
date: pure and simple: it's about MIN/MAXING meaningless numbers on what could otherwise be an Excel sheet. Except there's a guy yelling at you trying to be a funny british king figure
recommended: and failing hard at it.\n\nThis game is not worth it."

Tower Wars, what more is there to say? The game plays around the game mode made popular by War Craft III in which the player constructs towers in a maze to protect their base (or in this game's instance, their castle). Its a simple style of gameplay for a very casual game that can be both relaxing, or in more difficult settings absolutely intense. Unfortunately, Tower Wars fails to deliver on any of that excitement that made tower defence games so very popular in the years past.

A few review note this game as being easy, others stating that it is hard. Overall, the game is easy--until you hit the absolute best in any given map in which case its a waiting game for the creeps to get strong enough to make it to your castle. Games lasting an hour or more of just waiting for your maxed out maze to finally be defeated while you sit hopeless...and bored. That is the survival mode in a nutshell--lifeless and easy. Aided with a rather terrible user interface and rather bad maps it feels uninspired and a chore to get into.

There now is multiplayer too, which like one of the single player modes adds the the ability to spend gold to buy creeps" to send to the oppossing player's maze. reviewText:
Tower Wars offers a unique take on the tower defense strategy genre by incorporating the standard set of towers, upgrades, and abilities, with a competetive gaming approach. Here are the Pros and Cons:

Pros:
1. Steampunk-style art offers a new take on the tower defense genre.
2. Gameplay is straightforward and easy to pick up.
3. Different levels and a hex based grid allows for a unique game each time you play.

Cons:
1. Content-wise, the game lacks diversity. There is only one set of units and the only changes in style between opposing players is color.
2. MONUMENTALLY long loading times for a small game will make you wonder if the game has frozen while spinning up a map.
3. Limited replayability as the playerbase is lacking for matchmaking/competetive play.

Summary: At its current 2.00 sale price, Tower wars is a definite buy. Even if you only get about 10 games out of it before moving on to another title, this game does offer some intense competetive play - provided you have the patience to wait through the loading times.
